Award.AwardTitle: Support For The University Of Arizona Laboratory Of Tree-Ring Research

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Laboratory of Tree-Ring Research (LTRR) at the University of Arizona is the only source of archaeological tree-ring dates in western North America. With National Science Foundation (NSF) support, the LTRR operates an analysis program for tree-ring samples collected by LTRR and other archaeologists from Alaska to Argentina and from the Pacific Ocean to the Mississippi River. NSF support allows the program to keep pace with the ever growing demand for archaeological tree-ring dating, and to maintain high production levels and short turnaround times. On average, more than 1,000 dates from 4,000+ archaeological tree-ring samples are produced annually. These data are integrated into relevant archaeological contexts to construct refined cultural sequences and examine important issues of past human behavior that cannot be addressed without accurate, high resolution temporal control. Among these topics are absolute site, locality, and regional chronologies, social organization structure, intergroup interaction, and cultural adaptation to physical and social environments. The program actively promotes the expansion of archaeological tree-ring dating into new regions such as the Southwestern deserts, Great Basin, Great Plains, Rocky Mountains, Alaska, Mexico, and South America.

The project has additional intellectual merits. Exact dating and chronology building are crucial to understanding human behavior, human-environment interactions, and processes of sociocultural stability, variation, change, and social evolution. Either directly or indirectly (through tree-ring dated ceramics), tree-ring dating underlies the chronology of Southwestern prehistory and many aspects of the documented history of the region. The project also generates dendroclimatic reconstructions that are combined with reconstructions produced by other paleoenvironmental disciplines such as geology, pollen analysis, volcanology, and trace element studies. In addition to illuminating past environmental processes, these integrated reconstructions provide a solid empirical foundation for examining the interrelationships between human behavior and environmental variability. Finally, the project's efforts to expand research into areas previously thought to be unsuitable for archaeological tree-ring provide absolutely dated "hinge points" for archaeological chronologies in the Sonoran Desert, the Great Basin, the western Great Plains, northern Mexico, and South America.

The project has a wide range of broader impacts. Its findings are almost immediately integrated into undergraduate and graduate classes in anthropology, geosciences, and other disciplines at the University of Arizona and other academic institutions. In addition, the project interacts with K-12 programs and provides public tours of the facility; it provides instruction for visiting scholars from around the world and facilitates field and laboratory training for non-profit, governmental, private sector, and Native American programs. Students accrue particular benefits from the reduced cost of analysis, thus allowing them to conduct extensive research at lower costs. The LTRR tree-ring sample collections and data archives are unparalleled, easily accessed resources for archaeological research, and an under-construction digital database will enhance the research value of these resources. Increased understanding of long-term human adaptation to cultural and environmental variability and enhanced knowledge of past environmental processes help develop and implement environmental and social policy. Project personnel have contributed directly to formulating policy for managing cultural and natural resources by federal, local, and tribal land management agencies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Tree-ring dating is the most accurate and precise dating method available to scholars studying the recent past and has been developed at the Laboratory of Tree-Ring Research (LTRR) at the University of Arizona for more than 80 years.  This laboratory support grant had two major goals:  (1) the analysis of tree-ring samples submitted by outside researchers, students, and others to derive chronological, behavioral, and environmental information, and (2) to expand tree-ring dating beyond the boundaries of the traditional US Southwest.

 The grant resulted in several significant results from both externally and internally submitted samples. Samples submitted by both a nonprofit organization (Crow Canyon Archaeological Center) and a private sector firm (Woods Canyon Archaeological Consultants) yielded dates between AD 375 and AD 689. These early dates significantly enhance the early portion of the southwestern tree-ring chronology and can be used for additional research questions  Other significant results include new dates from (a) the Harris site (LA 1867), an important and famous Basketmaker III site in western New Mexico, (b)  dates from late 19th and early 20th century Hispano and Anglo homesteads in western New Mexico, (c) dates from the 18th-19th century Spanish San Miguel Church in central New Mexico, (d) a ring-width series  the Steens Mountain, Oregon area, (e) dates from 19th century settler cabins in east-central Montana, and (e) a ring series developed for ecological research on pinyon pine trees from central Nevada as part of chronology building efforts.  These results are contributing to understand past human land-use patterns, as well as to understanding past human-environment interaction. The submittors of these samples have yet to publish the results of their research, so their full impact is not yet known.

Internally collected samples include those collected by PI Towner from Skagway, Alaska that contribute to our understanding of the Klondike Gold Rush, but more importantly, are the first archaeological/historic tree-ring samples ever dated from SE Alaska.  This bodes well for expanding dendroarchaeology into the Pacific coast of Canada and the US. Towner also made significant contributions toward understanding cambium-peeled trees in the Southwest, a topic that is garnering increased attention here and elsewhere. Other significant results include dating the oldest standing adobe structure in southern New Mexico (the LC Ranch) in Gila, New Mexico; dating possibly the oldest standing adobe structure in southern Colorado at Casa de Crestones (Fred Birner). 

Significant results from students/collaborators include (1) examining ethnicity in late 19th and early 20th century Hispano and Anglo homesteads in western New Mexico, (2) identifying ancestral Hopi wood procurement variation from the San Francisco Peaks of northern Arizona, (3) modeling date distributions of Prehispanic sites in the Flagstaff, AZ area, (4) showing the significance of gravel mulch on Prehispanic agricultural  (cotton) fields in the northern Rio Grande, (5) dating kiva murals, twined sandals, and rock art in the Bears Ears area of southeast Utah, (6) examining the relationship between humans, bison, and fire ecology in the Canadian Rockies, and (7) using tree-ring and wiggle-matched radiocarbon dates to identify the occupational history of Montezuma Castle National Monument.

Three MA theses and one completed PhD dissertation have been aided by the project.  Two additional PhD dissertations are in progress and should be completed in 2020. 

Results from externally submitted  samples are communicated to the submittors via letter reports, so their impact will not be know until those reports are completed; tree-ring results are immediately incorporated into the LTRR database, however, according to our data sharing plan. The scholarly community and general public have been informed of the results via papers published in scholarly journals and general public magazines, as well asby presentation s at  local, regional, national, and international meetings.  Out results are also immediately incorporated into the LTRR Outreach program which reaches 12,000 K-12, College and University students, national,  tribal, and international visitors per year.  

This project has and will continue to have significant impacts on archaeology and other fields. The data generated are changing interpretations of the past in several areas, and helping to preserve information ab out America’s cultural patrimony that may otherwise be lost.

 


Last Modified: 12/30/2019
Modified by: Ronald Towner
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Tree-ring dating is the most accurate and precise dating method available to scholars studying the recent past and has been developed at the Laboratory of Tree-Ring Research (LTRR) at the University of Arizona for more than 80 years. This laboratory support grant had two major goals: (1) the analysis of tree-ring samples submitted by outside researchers, students, and others to derive chronological, behavioral, and environmental information, and (2) to expand tree-ring dating beyond the boundaries of the traditional US Southwest. The grant resulted in several significant results from both externally and internally submitted samples. Samples submitted by both a nonprofit organization (Crow Canyon Archaeological Center) and a private sector firm (Woods Canyon Archaeological Consultants) yielded dates between AD 375 and AD 689. These early dates significantly enhance the early portion of the southwestern tree-ring chronology and can be used for additional research questions Other significant results include new dates from (a) the Harris site (LA 1867), an important and famous Basketmaker III site in western New Mexico, (b) dates from late 19th and early 20th century Hispano and Anglo homesteads in western New Mexico, (c) dates from the 18th-19th century Spanish San Miguel Church in central New Mexico, (d) a ring-width series the Steens Mountain, Oregon area, (e) dates from 19th century settler cabins in east-central Montana, and (e) a ring series developed for ecological research on pinyon pine trees from central Nevada as part of chronology building efforts. These results are contributing to understand past human land-use patterns, as well as to understanding past human-environment interaction. The submittors of these samples have yet to publish the results of their research, so their full impact is not yet known. Internally collected samples include those collected by PI Towner from Skagway, Alaska that contribute to our understanding of the Klondike Gold Rush, but more importantly, are the first archaeological/historic tree-ring samples ever dated from SE Alaska. This bodes well for expanding dendroarchaeology into the Pacific coast of Canada and the US. Towner also made significant contributions toward understanding cambium-peeled trees in the Southwest, a topic that is garnering increased attention here and elsewhere. Other significant results include dating the oldest standing adobe structure in southern New Mexico (the LC Ranch) in Gila, New Mexico; dating possibly the oldest standing adobe structure in southern Colorado at Casa de Crestones (Fred Birner). Significant results from students/collaborators include (1) examining ethnicity in late 19th and early 20th century Hispano and Anglo homesteads in western New Mexico, (2) identifying ancestral Hopi wood procurement variation from the San Francisco Peaks of northern Arizona, (3) modeling date distributions of Prehispanic sites in the Flagstaff, AZ area, (4) showing the significance of gravel mulch on Prehispanic agricultural (cotton) fields in the northern Rio Grande, (5) dating kiva murals, twined sandals, and rock art in the Bears Ears area of southeast Utah, (6) examining the relationship between humans, bison, and fire ecology in the Canadian Rockies, and (7) using tree-ring and wiggle-matched radiocarbon dates to identify the occupational history of Montezuma Castle National Monument. Three MA theses and one completed PhD dissertation have been aided by the project. Two additional PhD dissertations are in progress and should be completed in 2020. Results from externally submitted samples are communicated to the submittors via letter reports, so their impact will not be know until those reports are completed; tree-ring results are immediately incorporated into the LTRR database, however, according to our data sharing plan. The scholarly community and general public have been informed of the results via papers published in scholarly journals and general public magazines, as well asby presentation s at local, regional, national, and international meetings. Out results are also immediately incorporated into the LTRR Outreach program which reaches 12,000 K-12, College and University students, national, tribal, and international visitors per year. This project has and will continue to have significant impacts on archaeology and other fields. The data generated are changing interpretations of the past in several areas, and helping to preserve information ab out America’s cultural patrimony that may otherwise be lost.
